hints_html:
Try a trig substitution.

Try the trig substitution \(x = 10\sin \theta\)

Later down the road you may want to use

\(\tan^{2}\theta = \sec^{2}\theta - 1\)

Don’t forget to plug back your original variables.
hints_latex:
Later down the road you may want to use

$\tan^{2}\theta = \sec^{2}\theta - 1$
Don't forget to plug back your original variables.
hints_raw:
Try a trig substitution.
Try the trig substitution <math> x = 10\sin \theta </math>
Later down the road you may want to use

<math>
\tan^{2}\theta = \sec^{2}\theta - 1
</math>
Don't forget to plug back your original variables.
question: 3 (c)
sols_html:
Let \(x = 10\sin \theta\) so that \(dx = 10\cos \theta d\theta\). Then we have

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{x^{2}} {(100-x^{2})^{3/2}} \, dx &= \int \frac{100\sin^{2}\theta (10\cos \theta d\theta)} {(100-100\sin^{2}\theta)^{3/2}}\\ &= \int \frac{1000(\sin^{2}\theta)(\cos \theta) d\theta} {(100\cos^{2}\theta)^{3/2}}\\ &= \int \frac{1000(\sin^{2}\theta)(\cos \theta) d\theta} {1000\cos^{3} \theta }\\ &= \int \frac{\sin^{2}\theta d\theta} {\cos^{2} \theta }\\ &= \int \tan^{2}\theta d\theta\\ &= \int (\sec^{2}\theta-1) d\theta\\ &= \tan\theta - \theta + C\end{aligned}\]

Now we isolate for the original variables. Using the diagram below (created from noting the original condition on x and by using Pythagorean theorem), we have

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{x^{2}} {(100-x^{2})^{3/2}} \, dx &= \tan\theta -\theta + C \\ &= \frac{x}{\sqrt{100-x^{2}}} - \arcsin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right) + C\end{aligned}\]

completing the proof.
sols_latex:
Let $x = 10\sin \theta$ so that $dx = 10\cos \theta d\theta$. Then we
have

\begin{align*}
\int \frac{x^{2}} {(100-x^{2})^{3/2}} \, dx &= \int \frac{100\sin^{2}\theta (10\cos \theta d\theta)} {(100-100\sin^{2}\theta)^{3/2}}\\
&= \int \frac{1000(\sin^{2}\theta)(\cos \theta) d\theta} {(100\cos^{2}\theta)^{3/2}}\\
&= \int \frac{1000(\sin^{2}\theta)(\cos \theta) d\theta} {1000\cos^{3} \theta }\\
&= \int \frac{\sin^{2}\theta d\theta} {\cos^{2} \theta }\\
&= \int \tan^{2}\theta d\theta\\
&= \int (\sec^{2}\theta-1) d\theta\\
&= \tan\theta - \theta + C
\end{align*}

Now we isolate for the original variables. Using the diagram below
(created from noting the original condition on \emph{x} and by using
Pythagorean theorem), we have

\begin{align*}
\int \frac{x^{2}} {(100-x^{2})^{3/2}} \, dx &=  \tan\theta -\theta + C \\
&= \frac{x}{\sqrt{100-x^{2}}} - \arcsin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right) + C
\end{align*}

completing the proof.

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH101/April_2006/MATH101Apr2006Q3c.jpeg}
sols_raw:
Let <math> x = 10\sin \theta</math> so that <math> dx = 10\cos \theta d\theta </math>. Then we have

<math> 
\begin{align}
\int \frac{x^{2}} {(100-x^{2})^{3/2}} \, dx &= \int \frac{100\sin^{2}\theta (10\cos \theta d\theta)} {(100-100\sin^{2}\theta)^{3/2}}\\
&= \int \frac{1000(\sin^{2}\theta)(\cos \theta) d\theta} {(100\cos^{2}\theta)^{3/2}}\\
&= \int \frac{1000(\sin^{2}\theta)(\cos \theta) d\theta} {1000\cos^{3} \theta }\\
&= \int \frac{\sin^{2}\theta d\theta} {\cos^{2} \theta }\\
&= \int \tan^{2}\theta d\theta\\
&= \int (\sec^{2}\theta-1) d\theta\\
&= \tan\theta - \theta + C
\end{align}
</math>

Now we isolate for the original variables. Using the diagram below (created from noting the original condition on ''x'' and by using Pythagorean theorem), we have

<math> 
\begin{align}
\int \frac{x^{2}} {(100-x^{2})^{3/2}} \, dx &=  \tan\theta -\theta + C \\
&= \frac{x}{\sqrt{100-x^{2}}} - \arcsin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right) + C\\
\end{align}
</math>

completing the proof.

statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. Justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required.

Evaluate the following integral.

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{x^{2}} {(100-x^{2})^{3/2}} \, dx\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
<b> Full-Solution Problems. Justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required. </b>

<b> Evaluate the following integral. </b>

:<math> \int \frac{x^{2}} {(100-x^{2})^{3/2}} \, dx </math>
